Initialize the metrics for testing each seen task in the beginning of a task's testing.

@rank_zero_only
def on_test_batch_end( self, trainer: lightning.pytorch.trainer.trainer.Trainer, pl_module: clarena.utils.eval.CULEvaluation, outputs: dict[str, typing.Any], batch: Any, batch_idx: int, dataloader_idx: int = 0) -> None: 
104    @rank_zero_only
105    def on_test_batch_end(
106        self,
107        trainer: Trainer,
108        pl_module: CULEvaluation,
109        outputs: dict[str, Any],
110        batch: Any,
111        batch_idx: int,
112        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
113    ) -> None:
114        r"""Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.
115
116        **Args:**
117        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the `test_step()` method in the `CULEvaluation`.
118        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
119        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
120        """
121
122        # get the batch size
123        batch_size = len(batch)
124
125        test_task_id = pl_module.get_test_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
126
127        # get the raw outputs from the outputs dictionary
128        agg_out_main = outputs["agg_out_main"]  # aggregated outputs from the main model
129        agg_out_ref = outputs[
130            "agg_out_ref"
131        ]  # aggregated outputs from the reference model
132
133        if agg_out_main.dim() != 2:
134            raise ValueError(
135                f"Expected aggregated outputs to be (batch_size, flattened feature), i.e. 2 dimension, but got {agg_out_main.dim()}."
136            )
137
138        if agg_out_ref.dim() != 2:
139            raise ValueError(
140                f"Expected aggregated outputs to be (batch_size, flattened feature), i.e. 2 dimension, but got {agg_out_ref.dim()}."
141            )
142
143        # calculate the distribution distance between the main and reference model outputs
144        if self.distribution_distance_type == "euclidean":
145            distance = torch.torch.norm(
146                agg_out_main - agg_out_ref, p=2, dim=-1
147            ).mean()  # Euclidean distance
148
149        elif self.distribution_distance_type == "cosine":
150            distance = (
151                1
152                - torch.nn.functional.cosine_similarity(
153                    agg_out_main, agg_out_ref, dim=-1
154                )
155            ).mean()  # cosine distance
156        elif self.distribution_distance_type == "manhattan":
157            distance = torch.norm(
158                agg_out_main - agg_out_ref, p=1, dim=-1
159            ).mean()  # Manhattan distance
160        else:
161            distance = None
162
163        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the metrics of the epoch
164        self.distribution_distance[f"{test_task_id}"].update(distance, batch_size)

Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.

Args:

  • outputs (dict[str, Any]): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the test_step() method in the CULEvaluation.
  • batch (Any): the validation data batch.
  • dataloader_idx (int): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a RuntimeError.
@rank_zero_only
def on_test_epoch_end( self, trainer: lightning.pytorch.trainer.trainer.Trainer, pl_module: clarena.utils.eval.CULEvaluation) -> None:

176            csv_path=self.distribution_distance_csv_path,
177        )
178        self.plot_unlearning_test_distance_from_csv(
179            csv_path=self.distribution_distance_csv_path,
180            plot_path=self.unlearning_test_distance_plot_path,
181        )

Save and plot test metrics at the end of test.

def update_unlearning_test_distance_to_csv( self, distance_metric: dict[str, clarena.utils.metrics.MeanMetricBatch], csv_path: str) -> None: 
183    def update_unlearning_test_distance_to_csv(
184        self,
185        distance_metric: dict[str, MeanMetricBatch],
186        csv_path: str,
187    ) -> None:
188        r"""Update the unlearning test distance metrics of unlearning tasks to CSV file.
189
190        **Args:**
191        - **distance_metric** (`dict[str, MeanMetricBatch]`): the distance metric of unlearned tasks. Accumulated and calculated from the unlearning test batches.
192        - **csv_path** (`str`): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/unlearning_test_after_task_X/distance.csv'.
193        """
194
195        eval_task_ids = list(distance_metric.keys())
196        fieldnames = ["average_distribution_distance"] + [
197            f"unlearning_test_on_task_{task_id}" for task_id in eval_task_ids
198        ]
199
200        new_line = {}
201
202        # write to the columns and calculate the average distribution distance over tasks at the same time
203        average_distribution_distance_over_unlearned_tasks = MeanMetric().to(
204            next(iter(distance_metric.values())).device
205        )
206        for task_id in eval_task_ids:
207            loss_cls = distance_metric[f"{task_id}"].compute().item()
208            new_line[f"unlearning_test_on_task_{task_id}"] = loss_cls
209            average_distribution_distance_over_unlearned_tasks(loss_cls)
210        new_line["average_distribution_distance"] = (
211            average_distribution_distance_over_unlearned_tasks.compute().item()
212        )
213
214        # write to the csv file
215        is_first = not os.path.exists(csv_path)
216        if not is_first:
217            with open(csv_path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as file:
218                lines = file.readlines()
219                del lines[0]
220        # write header
221        with open(csv_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as file:
222            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
223            writer.writeheader()
224        # write metrics
225        with open(csv_path, "a", encoding="utf-8") as file:
226            if not is_first:
227                file.writelines(lines)  # write the previous lines
228            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
229            writer.writerow(new_line)

class CULAccuracyDifference(clarena.metrics.MetricCallback): 
 27class CULAccuracyDifference(MetricCallback):
 28    r"""Provides all actions that are related to CUL accuracy difference (AD) metric, which include:
 29
 30    - Defining, initializing and recording AD metric.
 31    - Saving AD metric to files.
 32    - Visualizing AD metric as plots.
 33
 34    The callback is able to produce the following outputs:
 35
 36    - CSV files for AD in each task.
 37    - Coloured plot for AD in each task.
 38
 39    Note that this callback is designed to be used with the `CULEvaluation` module, which is a special evaluation module for continual unlearning. It is not a typical test step in the algorithm, but rather a test protocol that evaluates the performance of the model on unlearned tasks.
 40
 41    """
 42
 43    def __init__(
 44        self,
 45        save_dir: str,
 46        accuracy_difference_csv_name: str = "ad.csv",
 47        accuracy_difference_plot_name: str | None = None,
 48    ) -> None:
 49        r"""Initialize the `CULAccuracyDifference`.
 50
 51        **Args:**
 52        - **save_dir** (`str`): The directory where data and figures of metrics will be saved. Better inside the output folder.
 53        - **accuracy_difference_csv_name** (`str`): file name to save test accuracy difference metrics as CSV file.
 54        - **accuracy_difference_plot_name** (`str` | `None`): file name to save test accuracy difference metrics as plot. If `None`, no plot will be saved.
 55
 56        """
 57        super().__init__(save_dir=save_dir)
 58
 59        # paths
 60        self.accuracy_difference_csv_path: str = os.path.join(
 61            self.save_dir, accuracy_difference_csv_name
 62        )
 63        r"""Store the path to save the test accuracy difference metrics CSV file."""
 64        if accuracy_difference_plot_name:
 65            self.accuracy_difference_plot_path: str = os.path.join(
 66                self.save_dir, accuracy_difference_plot_name
 67            )
 68            r"""Store the path to save the test accuracy difference metrics plot file."""
 69
 70        # test accumulated metrics
 71        self.accuracy_difference: dict[str, MeanMetricBatch] = {}
 72        r"""Accuracy difference (between main and full model) metrics for each seen task. Accumulated and calculated from the test batches. Keys are task IDs and values are the corresponding metrics."""
 73
 74        self.task_id: int
 75        r"""Task ID counter indicating which task is being processed. Self updated during the task loop. Starting from 1. """

 77    @rank_zero_only
 78    def on_test_start(
 79        self,
 80        trainer: Trainer,
 81        pl_module: CULEvaluation,
 82    ) -> None:
 83        r"""Initialize the metrics for testing each seen task in the beginning of a task's testing."""
 84
 85        # get the device to put the metrics on the same device
 86        device = pl_module.device
 87
 88        # initialize test metrics for evaluation tasks
 89        self.accuracy_difference = {
 90            f"{task_id}": MeanMetricBatch().to(device)
 91            for task_id in pl_module.ad_eval_task_ids
 92        }
 93
 94    @rank_zero_only
 95    def on_test_batch_end(
 96        self,
 97        trainer: Trainer,
 98        pl_module: CULEvaluation,
 99        outputs: dict[str, Any],
100        batch: Any,
101        batch_idx: int,
102        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
103    ) -> None:
104        r"""Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.
105
106        **Args:**
107        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the `test_step()` method in the `CULEvaluation`.
108        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
109        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
110        """
111
112        # get the batch size
113        batch_size = len(batch)
114
115        test_task_id = pl_module.get_test_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
116
117        # get the metrics values of the batch from the outputs
118        acc_diff = outputs["acc_diff"]  # accuracy difference
119
120        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the metrics of the epoch
121        self.accuracy_difference[f"{test_task_id}"].update(acc_diff, batch_size)

140    def update_unlearning_accuracy_difference_to_csv(
141        self,
142        accuracy_difference_metric: dict[str, MeanMetricBatch],
143        csv_path: str,
144    ) -> None:

146
147        **Args:**
148        - **accuracy_difference_metric** (`dict[str, MeanMetricBatch]`): the accuracy difference metric. Accumulated and calculated from the unlearning test batches.
149        - **csv_path** (`str`): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/unlearning_test_after_task_X/distance.csv'.
150        """
151
152        eval_task_ids = list(accuracy_difference_metric.keys())
153        fieldnames = ["average_accuracy_difference"] + [
154            f"unlearning_test_on_task_{task_id}" for task_id in eval_task_ids
155        ]
156
157        new_line = {}
158
159        # write to the columns and calculate the average accuracy difference over tasks at the same time
160        average_accuracy_difference_over_unlearned_tasks = MeanMetric().to(
161            next(iter(accuracy_difference_metric.values())).device
162        )
163        for task_id in eval_task_ids:
164            loss_cls = accuracy_difference_metric[f"{task_id}"].compute().item()
165            new_line[f"unlearning_test_on_task_{task_id}"] = loss_cls
166            average_accuracy_difference_over_unlearned_tasks(loss_cls)
167        new_line["average_accuracy_difference"] = (
168            average_accuracy_difference_over_unlearned_tasks.compute().item()
169        )
170
171        # write to the csv file
172        is_first = not os.path.exists(csv_path)
173        if not is_first:
174            with open(csv_path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as file:
175                lines = file.readlines()
176                del lines[0]
177        # write header
178        with open(csv_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as file:
179            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
180            writer.writeheader()
181        # write metrics
182        with open(csv_path, "a", encoding="utf-8") as file:
183            if not is_first:
184                file.writelines(lines)  # write the previous lines
185            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
186            writer.writerow(new_line)
187
188    def plot_unlearning_accuracy_difference_from_csv(
189        self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str
190    ) -> None:
191        """Plot the unlearning accuracy difference matrix over different unlearned tasks from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.
192
193        **Args:**
194        - **csv_path** (`str`): the path to the CSV file where the `utils.save_unlearning_test_distance_to_csv()` saved the unlearning test distance metric.
195        - **plot_path** (`str`): the path to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/unlearning_test_after_task_X/distance.png'.
196        """
197        data = pd.read_csv(csv_path)
198
199        unlearned_task_ids = [
200            int(col.replace("unlearning_test_on_task_", ""))
201            for col in data.columns
202            if col.startswith("unlearning_test_on_task_")
203        ]
204        num_tasks = len(unlearned_task_ids)
205        num_tests = len(data)
206
207        # plot the accuracy matrix
208        fig, ax = plt.subplots(
209            figsize=(2 * (num_tasks + 1), 2 * (num_tests + 1))
210        )  # adaptive figure size
211        cax = ax.imshow(
212            data.drop(["average_accuracy_difference"], axis=1),
213            interpolation="nearest",
214            cmap="Greens",
215            vmin=0,
216            vmax=1,
217        )
218
219        colorbar = fig.colorbar(cax)
220        yticks = colorbar.ax.get_yticks()
221        colorbar.ax.set_yticks(yticks)
222        colorbar.ax.set_yticklabels(
223            [f"{tick:.2f}" for tick in yticks], fontsize=10 + num_tasks
224        )  # adaptive font size
225
226        r = 0
227        for r in range(num_tests):
228            for c in range(num_tasks):
229                j = unlearned_task_ids[c]
230                s = (
231                    f"{data.loc[r, f'unlearning_test_on_task_{j}']:.3f}"
232                    if f"unlearning_test_on_task_{j}" in data.columns
233                    else ""
234                )
235                ax.text(
236                    c,
237                    r,
238                    s,
239                    ha="center",
240                    va="center",
241                    color="black",
242                    fontsize=10 + num_tasks,  # adaptive font size
243                )
244
245        ax.set_xticks(range(num_tasks))
246        ax.set_yticks(range(num_tests))
247        ax.set_xticklabels(
248            unlearned_task_ids, fontsize=10 + num_tasks
249        )  # adaptive font size
250        ax.set_yticklabels(
251            range(1, num_tests + 1), fontsize=10 + num_tests
252        )  # adaptive font size
253
254        # Labeling the axes
255        ax.set_xlabel(
256            "Testing unlearning on task τ", fontsize=10 + num_tasks
257        )  # adaptive font size
258        ax.set_ylabel(
259            "Unlearning test after training task t", fontsize=10 + num_tasks
260        )  # adaptive font size
261        fig.savefig(plot_path)
262        plt.close(fig)

Provides all actions that are related to CUL accuracy difference (AD) metric, which include:

  • Defining, initializing and recording AD metric.
  • Saving AD metric to files.
  • Visualizing AD metric as plots.

The callback is able to produce the following outputs:

  • CSV files for AD in each task.
  • Coloured plot for AD in each task.

Note that this callback is designed to be used with the CULEvaluation module, which is a special evaluation module for continual unlearning. It is not a typical test step in the algorithm, but rather a test protocol that evaluates the performance of the model on unlearned tasks.

CULAccuracyDifference( save_dir: str, accuracy_difference_csv_name: str = 'ad.csv', accuracy_difference_plot_name: str | None = None)

74        self.task_id: int
75        r"""Task ID counter indicating which task is being processed. Self updated during the task loop. Starting from 1. """

@rank_zero_only
def on_test_batch_end( self, trainer: lightning.pytorch.trainer.trainer.Trainer, pl_module: clarena.utils.eval.CULEvaluation, outputs: dict[str, typing.Any], batch: Any, batch_idx: int, dataloader_idx: int = 0) -> None: 
 94    @rank_zero_only
 95    def on_test_batch_end(
 96        self,
 97        trainer: Trainer,
 98        pl_module: CULEvaluation,
 99        outputs: dict[str, Any],
100        batch: Any,
101        batch_idx: int,
102        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
103    ) -> None:
104        r"""Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.
105
106        **Args:**
107        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the `test_step()` method in the `CULEvaluation`.
108        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
109        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
110        """
111
112        # get the batch size
113        batch_size = len(batch)
114
115        test_task_id = pl_module.get_test_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
116
117        # get the metrics values of the batch from the outputs
118        acc_diff = outputs["acc_diff"]  # accuracy difference
119
120        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the metrics of the epoch
121        self.accuracy_difference[f"{test_task_id}"].update(acc_diff, batch_size)

Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.

Args:

  • outputs (dict[str, Any]): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the test_step() method in the CULEvaluation.
  • batch (Any): the validation data batch.
  • dataloader_idx (int): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a RuntimeError.

def update_unlearning_accuracy_difference_to_csv( self, accuracy_difference_metric: dict[str, clarena.utils.metrics.MeanMetricBatch], csv_path: str) -> None: 
140    def update_unlearning_accuracy_difference_to_csv(
141        self,
142        accuracy_difference_metric: dict[str, MeanMetricBatch],
143        csv_path: str,
144    ) -> None:
145        r"""Update the unlearning accuracy difference metrics of unlearning tasks to CSV file.
146
147        **Args:**
148        - **accuracy_difference_metric** (`dict[str, MeanMetricBatch]`): the accuracy difference metric. Accumulated and calculated from the unlearning test batches.
149        - **csv_path** (`str`): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/unlearning_test_after_task_X/distance.csv'.
150        """
151
152        eval_task_ids = list(accuracy_difference_metric.keys())
153        fieldnames = ["average_accuracy_difference"] + [
154            f"unlearning_test_on_task_{task_id}" for task_id in eval_task_ids
155        ]
156
157        new_line = {}
158
159        # write to the columns and calculate the average accuracy difference over tasks at the same time
160        average_accuracy_difference_over_unlearned_tasks = MeanMetric().to(
161            next(iter(accuracy_difference_metric.values())).device
162        )
163        for task_id in eval_task_ids:
164            loss_cls = accuracy_difference_metric[f"{task_id}"].compute().item()
165            new_line[f"unlearning_test_on_task_{task_id}"] = loss_cls
166            average_accuracy_difference_over_unlearned_tasks(loss_cls)
167        new_line["average_accuracy_difference"] = (
168            average_accuracy_difference_over_unlearned_tasks.compute().item()
169        )
170
171        # write to the csv file
172        is_first = not os.path.exists(csv_path)
173        if not is_first:
174            with open(csv_path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as file:
175                lines = file.readlines()
176                del lines[0]
177        # write header
178        with open(csv_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as file:
179            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
180            writer.writeheader()
181        # write metrics
182        with open(csv_path, "a", encoding="utf-8") as file:
183            if not is_first:
184                file.writelines(lines)  # write the previous lines
185            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
186            writer.writerow(new_line)

  • csv_path (str): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/unlearning_test_after_task_X/distance.csv'.

class HATAdjustmentRate(clarena.metrics.MetricCallback): 
 25class HATAdjustmentRate(MetricCallback):
 26    r"""Provides all actions that are related to adjustment rate of [HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a) algorithm and its extensions, which include:
 27
 28    - Visualizing adjustment rate during training as figures.
 29
 30    The callback is able to produce the following outputs:
 31
 32    - Figures of training adjustment rate.
 33
 34    """
 35
 36    def __init__(
 37        self,
 38        save_dir: str,
 39        plot_adjustment_rate_every_n_steps: int | None = None,
 40    ) -> None:
 41        r"""Initialize the `HATAdjustmentRate`.
 42
 43        **Args:**
 44        - **save_dir** (`str` | `None`): The directory to save the adjustment rate figures. Better inside the output folder.
 45        - **plot_adjustment_rate_every_n_steps** (`int` | `None`): the frequency of plotting adjustment rate figures in terms of number of batches during training.
 46        """
 47        super().__init__(save_dir=save_dir)
 48
 49        # other settings
 50        self.plot_adjustment_rate_every_n_steps: int = (
 51            plot_adjustment_rate_every_n_steps
 52        )
 53        r"""Store the frequency of plotting adjustment rate in terms of number of batches."""
 54
 55        self.task_id: int
 56        r"""Task ID counter indicating which task is being processed. Self updated during the task loop. Starting from 1. """
 57
 58    def on_fit_start(self, trainer: Trainer, pl_module: CLAlgorithm) -> None:
 59        r"""Get the current task ID in the beginning of a task's fitting (training and validation). Sanity check the `pl_module` to be `HAT`.
 60
 61        **Raises:**
 62        -**TypeError**: when the `pl_module` is not `HAT`.
 63        """
 64
 65        # get the current task_id from the `CLAlgorithm` object
 66        self.task_id = pl_module.task_id
 67
 68        # sanity check
 69        if not isinstance(pl_module, HAT):
 70            raise TypeError(
 71                "The `CLAlgorithm` should be `HAT` to apply `HATAdjustmentRate`!"
 72            )
 73
 74    @rank_zero_only
 75    def on_train_batch_end(
 76        self,
 77        trainer: Trainer,
 78        pl_module: CLAlgorithm,
 79        outputs: dict[str, Any],
 80        batch: Any,
 81        batch_idx: int,
 82    ) -> None:
 83        r"""Plot adjustment rate after training batch.
 84
 85        **Args:**
 86        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the training step, which is the returns of the `training_step()` method in the `CLAlgorithm`.
 87        - **batch** (`Any`): the training data batch.
 88        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is for the file name of mask figures.
 89        """
 90
 91        # get the adjustment rate
 92        adjustment_rate_weight = outputs["adjustment_rate_weight"]
 93        adjustment_rate_bias = outputs["adjustment_rate_bias"]
 94
 95        # plot the adjustment rate
 96        if self.save_dir is not None:
 97            if self.task_id > 1:
 98                if batch_idx % self.plot_adjustment_rate_every_n_steps == 0:
 99                    self.plot_hat_adjustment_rate(
100                        adjustment_rate=adjustment_rate_weight,
101                        weight_or_bias="weight",
102                        step=batch_idx,
103                    )
104                    self.plot_hat_adjustment_rate(
105                        adjustment_rate=adjustment_rate_bias,
106                        weight_or_bias="bias",
107                        step=batch_idx,
108                    )
109
110    def plot_hat_adjustment_rate(
111        self,
112        adjustment_rate: dict[str, Tensor],
113        weight_or_bias: str,
114        step: int | None = None,
115    ) -> None:
116        """Plot adjustment rate in [HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a)) algorithm. This includes the adjustment rate weight and adjustment rate bias (if applicable).
117
118        **Args:**
119        - **adjustment_rate** (`dict[str, Tensor]`): the adjustment rate. Key (`str`) is layer name, value (`Tensor`) is the adjustment rate tensor. If it's adjustment rate weight, it has size same as weights. If it's adjustment rate bias, it has size same as biases.
120        - **weight_or_bias** (`str`): the type of adjustment rate. It can be either 'weight' or 'bias'. This is to form the plot name.
121        - **step** (`int`): the training step (batch index) of the adjustment rate to be plotted. This is to form the plot name. Keep `None` for not showing the step in the plot name.
122        """
123
124        for layer_name, a in adjustment_rate.items():
125            layer_name = layer_name.replace(
126                "/", "."
127            )  # the layer name contains '/', which is not allowed in the file name. We replace it back with '.'.
128
129            if weight_or_bias == "bias":
130                a = a.view(
131                    1, -1
132                )  # reshape the 1D mask to 2D so can be plotted by image show
133
134            fig = plt.figure()
135            plt.imshow(
136                a.detach().cpu(),
137                aspect="auto",
138                cmap="Wistia",
139                norm=LogNorm(vmin=1e-7, vmax=1e-5),
140            )  # can only convert to tensors in CPU to numpy arrays
141            plt.yticks()  # hide yticks
142            plt.colorbar()
143            if step:
144                plot_name = (
145                    f"{layer_name}_{weight_or_bias}_task{self.task_id}_step{step}.png"
146                )
147            else:
148                plot_name = f"{layer_name}_{weight_or_bias}_task{self.task_id}.png"
149            plot_path = os.path.join(self.save_dir, plot_name)
150            fig.savefig(plot_path)
151            plt.close(fig)

  • Figures of training adjustment rate.

def plot_hat_adjustment_rate( self, adjustment_rate: dict[str, torch.Tensor], weight_or_bias: str, step: int | None = None) -> None: 
110    def plot_hat_adjustment_rate(
111        self,
112        adjustment_rate: dict[str, Tensor],
113        weight_or_bias: str,
114        step: int | None = None,
115    ) -> None:
116        """Plot adjustment rate in [HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a)) algorithm. This includes the adjustment rate weight and adjustment rate bias (if applicable).
117
118        **Args:**
119        - **adjustment_rate** (`dict[str, Tensor]`): the adjustment rate. Key (`str`) is layer name, value (`Tensor`) is the adjustment rate tensor. If it's adjustment rate weight, it has size same as weights. If it's adjustment rate bias, it has size same as biases.
120        - **weight_or_bias** (`str`): the type of adjustment rate. It can be either 'weight' or 'bias'. This is to form the plot name.
121        - **step** (`int`): the training step (batch index) of the adjustment rate to be plotted. This is to form the plot name. Keep `None` for not showing the step in the plot name.
122        """
123
124        for layer_name, a in adjustment_rate.items():
125            layer_name = layer_name.replace(
126                "/", "."
127            )  # the layer name contains '/', which is not allowed in the file name. We replace it back with '.'.
128
129            if weight_or_bias == "bias":
130                a = a.view(
131                    1, -1
132                )  # reshape the 1D mask to 2D so can be plotted by image show
133
134            fig = plt.figure()
135            plt.imshow(
136                a.detach().cpu(),
137                aspect="auto",
138                cmap="Wistia",
139                norm=LogNorm(vmin=1e-7, vmax=1e-5),
140            )  # can only convert to tensors in CPU to numpy arrays
141            plt.yticks()  # hide yticks
142            plt.colorbar()
143            if step:
144                plot_name = (
145                    f"{layer_name}_{weight_or_bias}_task{self.task_id}_step{step}.png"
146                )
147            else:
148                plot_name = f"{layer_name}_{weight_or_bias}_task{self.task_id}.png"
149            plot_path = os.path.join(self.save_dir, plot_name)
150            fig.savefig(plot_path)
151            plt.close(fig)

Plot adjustment rate in HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)) algorithm. This includes the adjustment rate weight and adjustment rate bias (if applicable).

Args:

  • adjustment_rate (dict[str, Tensor]): the adjustment rate. Key (str) is layer name, value (Tensor) is the adjustment rate tensor. If it's adjustment rate weight, it has size same as weights. If it's adjustment rate bias, it has size same as biases.
  • weight_or_bias (str): the type of adjustment rate. It can be either 'weight' or 'bias'. This is to form the plot name.
  • step (int): the training step (batch index) of the adjustment rate to be plotted. This is to form the plot name. Keep None for not showing the step in the plot name.
class HATNetworkCapacity(clarena.metrics.MetricCallback): 
21class HATNetworkCapacity(MetricCallback):
22    r"""Provides all actions that are related to network capacity of [HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a) algorithm and its extensions, which include:
23
24    - Logging network capacity during training. See the "Evaluation Metrics" section in chapter 4.1 in [AdaHAT paper](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-70352-2_9) for more details about network capacity.
25
26    """
27
28    def __init__(
29        self,
30        save_dir: str,
31    ) -> None:
32        r"""Initialize the `HATNetworkCapacity`.
33
34        **Args:**
35        - **save_dir** (`str`): the directory to save the mask figures. Better inside the output folder.
36        """
37        super().__init__(save_dir=save_dir)
38
39        self.task_id: int
40        r"""Task ID counter indicating which task is being processed. Self updated during the task loop. Starting from 1. """
41
42    def on_fit_start(self, trainer: Trainer, pl_module: CLAlgorithm) -> None:
43        r"""Get the current task ID in the beginning of a task's fitting (training and validation). Sanity check the `pl_module` to be `HAT`.
44
45        **Raises:**
46        -**TypeError**: when the `pl_module` is not `HAT`.
47        """
48
49        # get the current task_id from the `CLAlgorithm` object
50        self.task_id = pl_module.task_id
51
52        # sanity check
53        if not isinstance(pl_module, HAT):
54            raise TypeError(
55                "The `CLAlgorithm` should be `HAT` to apply `HATMetricCallback`!"
56            )
57
58    @rank_zero_only
59    def on_train_batch_end(
60        self,
61        trainer: Trainer,
62        pl_module: CLAlgorithm,
63        outputs: dict[str, Any],
64        batch: Any,
65        batch_idx: int,
66    ) -> None:
67        r"""Plot training mask, adjustment rate and log network capacity after training batch.
68
69        **Args:**
70        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the training step, which is the returns of the `training_step()` method in the `CLAlgorithm`.
71        - **batch** (`Any`): the training data batch.
72        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is for the file name of mask figures.
73        """
74
75        # get the current network capacity
76        capacity = outputs["capacity"]
77
78        # log the network capacity to Lightning loggers
79        pl_module.log(
80            f"task_{self.task_id}/train/network_capacity", capacity, prog_bar=True
81        )

class HATMasks(clarena.metrics.MetricCallback): 
 24class HATMasks(MetricCallback):
 25    r"""Provides all actions that are related to masks of [HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a) algorithm and its extensions, which include:
 26
 27    - Visualizing mask and cumulative mask figures during training and testing as figures.
 28
 29    The callback is able to produce the following outputs:
 30
 31    - Figures of both training and test, masks and cumulative masks.
 32
 33    """
 34
 35    def __init__(
 36        self,
 37        save_dir: str,
 38        test_masks_dir_name: str | None = None,
 39        test_cumulative_masks_dir_name: str | None = None,
 40        training_masks_dir_name: str | None = None,
 41        plot_training_mask_every_n_steps: int | None = None,
 42    ) -> None:
 43        r"""Initialize the `HATMasks`.
 44
 45        **Args:**
 46        - **save_dir** (`str`): the directory to save the mask figures. Better inside the output folder.
 47        - **test_masks_dir_name** (`str` | `None`): the relative path to `save_dir` to save the test mask figures. If `None`, no file will be saved.
 48        - **test_cumulative_masks_dir_name** (`str` | `None`): the directory to save the test cumulative mask figures. If `None`, no file will be saved.
 49        - **training_masks_dir_name** (`str` | `None`): the directory to save the training mask figures. If `None`, no file will be saved.
 50        - **plot_training_mask_every_n_steps** (`int` | `None`): the frequency of plotting training mask figures in terms of number of batches during training. Only applies when `training_masks_dir_name` is not `None`.
 51        """
 52        super().__init__(save_dir=save_dir)
 53
 54        # paths
 55        if test_masks_dir_name is not None:
 56            self.test_masks_dir: str = os.path.join(self.save_dir, test_masks_dir_name)
 57            r"""Store the directory to save the test mask figures."""
 58        if test_cumulative_masks_dir_name is not None:
 59            self.test_cumulative_masks_dir: str = os.path.join(
 60                self.save_dir, test_cumulative_masks_dir_name
 61            )
 62            r"""Store the directory to save the test cumulative mask figures."""
 63        if training_masks_dir_name is not None:
 64            self.training_masks_dir: str = os.path.join(
 65                self.save_dir, training_masks_dir_name
 66            )
 67            r"""Store the directory to save the training mask figures."""
 68
 69        # other settings
 70        self.plot_training_mask_every_n_steps: int = plot_training_mask_every_n_steps
 71        r"""Store the frequency of plotting training masks in terms of number of batches."""
 72
 73        self.task_id: int
 74        r"""Task ID counter indicating which task is being processed. Self updated during the task loop. Starting from 1. """
 75
 76    def on_fit_start(self, trainer: Trainer, pl_module: CLAlgorithm) -> None:
 77        r"""Get the current task ID in the beginning of a task's fitting (training and validation). Sanity check the `pl_module` to be `HAT`.
 78
 79        **Raises:**
 80        -**TypeError**: when the `pl_module` is not `HAT`.
 81        """
 82
 83        # get the current task_id from the `CLAlgorithm` object
 84        self.task_id = pl_module.task_id
 85
 86        # sanity check
 87        if not isinstance(pl_module, HAT):
 88            raise TypeError("The `CLAlgorithm` should be `HAT` to apply `HATMasks`!")
 89
 90    @rank_zero_only
 91    def on_train_batch_end(
 92        self,
 93        trainer: Trainer,
 94        pl_module: CLAlgorithm,
 95        outputs: dict[str, Any],
 96        batch: Any,
 97        batch_idx: int,
 98    ) -> None:
 99        r"""Plot training mask after training batch.
100
101        **Args:**
102        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the training step, which is the returns of the `training_step()` method in the `CLAlgorithm`.
103        - **batch** (`Any`): the training data batch.
104        - **batch_idx** (`int`): the index of the current batch. This is for the file name of mask figures.
105        """
106
107        # get the mask over the model after training the batch
108        mask = outputs["mask"]
109
110        # plot the mask
111        if self.training_masks_dir is not None:
112            if batch_idx % self.plot_training_mask_every_n_steps == 0:
113                self.plot_hat_mask(
114                    mask=mask,
115                    plot_dir=self.training_masks_dir,
116                    task_id=self.task_id,
117                    step=batch_idx,
118                )
119
120    @rank_zero_only
121    def on_test_start(self, trainer: Trainer, pl_module: CLAlgorithm) -> None:
122        r"""Plot test mask and cumulative mask figures."""
123
124        # test mask
125        mask = pl_module.masks[f"{self.task_id}"]
126        self.plot_hat_mask(
127            mask=mask, plot_dir=self.test_masks_dir, task_id=self.task_id
128        )
129
130        # cumulative mask
131        cumulative_mask = pl_module.cumulative_mask_for_previous_tasks
132        self.plot_hat_mask(
133            mask=cumulative_mask,
134            plot_dir=self.test_cumulative_masks_dir,
135            task_id=self.task_id,
136        )
137
138    def plot_hat_mask(
139        self,
140        mask: dict[str, Tensor],
141        plot_dir: str,
142        task_id: int,
143        step: int | None = None,
144    ) -> None:
145        """Plot mask in [HAT (Hard Attention to the Task)](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v80/serra18a)) algorithm. This includes the mask and cumulative mask.
146
147        **Args:**
148        - **mask** (`dict[str, Tensor]`): the hard attention (whose values are 0 or 1) mask. Key (`str`) is layer name, value (`Tensor`) is the mask tensor. The mask tensor has size (number of units, ).
149        - **plot_dir** (`str`): the directory to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment.
150        - **task_id** (`int`): the task ID of the mask to be plotted. This is to form the plot name.
151        - **step** (`int`): the training step (batch index) of the mask to be plotted. Apply to the training mask only. This is to form the plot name. Keep `None` for not showing the step in the plot name.
152        """
153
154        for layer_name, m in mask.items():
155            layer_name = layer_name.replace(
156                "/", "."
157            )  # the layer name contains '/', which is not allowed in the file name. We replace it back with '.'.
158
159            m = m.view(
160                1, -1
161            )  # reshape the 1D mask to 2D so can be plotted by image show
162
163            fig = plt.figure()
164            plt.imshow(
165                m.detach().cpu(), aspect="auto", cmap="Greys"
166            )  # can only convert to tensors in CPU to numpy arrays
167            plt.yticks()  # hide yticks
168            plt.colorbar()
169            if step:
170                plot_name = f"{layer_name}_task{task_id}_step{step}.png"
171            else:
172                plot_name = f"{layer_name}_task{task_id}.png"
173            plot_path = os.path.join(plot_dir, plot_name)
174            fig.savefig(plot_path)
175            plt.close(fig)
176            plt.close(fig)
177            plt.close(fig)

  • Visualizing mask and cumulative mask figures during training and testing as figures.

The callback is able to produce the following outputs:

  • Figures of both training and test, masks and cumulative masks.

  • mask (dict[str, Tensor]): the hard attention (whose values are 0 or 1) mask. Key (str) is layer name, value (Tensor) is the mask tensor. The mask tensor has size (number of units, ).
  • plot_dir (str): the directory to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment.
  • task_id (int): the task ID of the mask to be plotted. This is to form the plot name.
  • step (int): the training step (batch index) of the mask to be plotted. Apply to the training mask only. This is to form the plot name. Keep None for not showing the step in the plot name.
class MTLAccuracy(clarena.metrics.MetricCallback): 
 26class MTLAccuracy(MetricCallback):
 27    r"""Provides all actions that are related to MTL accuracy metrics, which include:
 28
 29    - Defining, initializing and recording accuracy metric.
 30    - Logging training and validation accuracy metric to Lightning loggers in real time.
 31    - Saving test accuracy metric to files.
 32    - Visualizing test accuracy metric as plots.
 33
 34    The callback is able to produce the following outputs:
 35
 36    - CSV files for test accuracy of all tasks and average accuracy.
 37    - Bar charts for test accuracy of all tasks.
 38    """
 39
 40    def __init__(
 41        self,
 42        save_dir: str,
 43        test_acc_csv_name: str = "acc.csv",
 44        test_acc_plot_name: str | None = None,
 45    ) -> None:
 46        r"""Initialize the `MTLAccuracy`.
 47
 48        **Args:**
 49        - **save_dir** (`str`): The directory where data and figures of metrics will be saved. Better inside the output folder.
 50        - **test_acc_csv_name** (`str`): file name to save test accuracy of all tasks and average accuracy as CSV file.
 51        - **test_acc_plot_name** (`str` | `None`): file name to save accuracy plot. If `None`, no file will be saved.
 52        """
 53        super().__init__(save_dir=save_dir)
 54
 55        # paths
 56        self.test_acc_csv_path: str = os.path.join(save_dir, test_acc_csv_name)
 57        r"""The path to save test accuracy of all tasks and average accuracy CSV file."""
 58        if test_acc_plot_name:
 59            self.test_acc_plot_path: str = os.path.join(save_dir, test_acc_plot_name)
 60            r"""The path to save test accuracy plot."""
 61
 62        # training accumulated metrics
 63        self.acc_training_epoch: MeanMetricBatch
 64        r"""Classification accuracy of training epoch. Accumulated and calculated from the training batches. """
 65
 66        # validation accumulated metrics
 67        self.acc_val: dict[int, MeanMetricBatch] = {}
 68        r"""Validation classification accuracy of the model after training epoch. Accumulated and calculated from the validation batches. Keys are task IDs and values are the corresponding metrics."""
 69
 70        # test accumulated metrics
 71        self.acc_test: dict[int, MeanMetricBatch] = {}
 72        r"""Test classification accuracy of all tasks. Accumulated and calculated from the test batches. Keys are task IDs and values are the corresponding metrics."""
 73
 74    def on_fit_start(self, trainer: Trainer, pl_module: MTLAlgorithm) -> None:
 75        r"""Initialize training and validation metrics."""
 76
 77        # initialize training metrics
 78        self.acc_training_epoch = MeanMetricBatch()
 79
 80        # initialize validation metrics
 81        self.acc_val = {
 82            task_id: MeanMetricBatch() for task_id in trainer.datamodule.train_tasks
 83        }
 84
 85    def on_train_batch_end(
 86        self,
 87        trainer: Trainer,
 88        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
 89        outputs: dict[str, Any],
 90        batch: Any,
 91        batch_idx: int,
 92    ) -> None:
 93        r"""Record training metrics from training batch, log metrics of training batch and accumulated metrics of the epoch to Lightning loggers.
 94
 95        **Args:**
 96        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the training step, the returns of the `training_step()` method in the `MTLAlgorithm`.
 97        - **batch** (`Any`): the training data batch.
 98        """
 99        # get the batch size
100        batch_size = len(batch)
101
102        # get training metrics values of current training batch from the outputs of the `training_step()`
103        acc_batch = outputs["acc"]
104
105        # update accumulated training metrics to calculate training metrics of the epoch
106        self.acc_training_epoch.update(acc_batch, batch_size)
107
108        # log training metrics of current training batch to Lightning loggers
109        pl_module.log("train/acc_batch", acc_batch, prog_bar=True)
110
111        # log accumulated training metrics till this training batch to Lightning loggers
112        pl_module.log(
113            "task/train/acc",
114            self.acc_training_epoch.compute(),
115            prog_bar=True,
116        )
117
118    def on_train_epoch_end(
119        self,
120        trainer: Trainer,
121        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
122    ) -> None:
123        r"""Log metrics of training epoch to plot learning curves and reset the metrics accumulation at the end of training epoch."""
124
125
126        # reset the metrics of training epoch as there are more epochs to go and not only one epoch like in the validation and test
127        self.acc_training_epoch.reset()
128
129    def on_validation_batch_end(
130        self,
131        trainer: Trainer,
132        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
133        outputs: dict[str, Any],
134        batch: Any,
135        batch_idx: int,
136        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
137    ) -> None:
138        r"""Accumulating metrics from validation batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of validation batches.
139
140        **Args:**
141        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the validation step, which is the returns of the `validation_step()` method in the `MTLAlgorithm`.
142        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
143        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of the validation dataloader. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
144        """
145
146        # get the batch size
147        batch_size = len(batch)
148
149        val_task_id = pl_module.get_val_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
150
151        # get the metrics values of the batch from the outputs
152        acc_batch = outputs["acc"]
153
154        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the validation metrics
155        self.acc_val[val_task_id].update(acc_batch, batch_size)
156
157    def on_test_start(
158        self,
159        trainer: Trainer,
160        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
161    ) -> None:
162        r"""Initialize the metrics for testing each seen task in the beginning of a task's testing."""
163
164        # initialize test metrics for current and previous tasks
165        self.acc_test = {
166            task_id: MeanMetricBatch() for task_id in trainer.datamodule.eval_tasks
167        }
168
169    def on_test_batch_end(
170        self,
171        trainer: Trainer,
172        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
173        outputs: dict[str, Any],
174        batch: Any,
175        batch_idx: int,
176        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
177    ) -> None:
178        r"""Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.
179
180        **Args:**
181        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the `test_step()` method in the `MTLAlgorithm`.
182        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
183        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
184        """
185
186        # get the batch size
187        batch_size = len(batch)
188
189        test_task_id = pl_module.get_test_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
190
191        # get the metrics values of the batch from the outputs
192        acc_batch = outputs["acc"]
193
194        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the metrics of the epoch
195        self.acc_test[test_task_id].update(acc_batch, batch_size)
196
197    def on_test_epoch_end(
198        self,
199        trainer: Trainer,
200        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
201    ) -> None:
202        r"""Save and plot test metrics at the end of test."""
203
204        # save (update) the test metrics to CSV files
205        self.save_test_acc_to_csv(
206            csv_path=self.test_acc_csv_path,
207        )
208
209        # plot the test metrics
210        if self.test_acc_plot_path:
211            self.plot_test_acc_from_csv(
212                csv_path=self.test_acc_csv_path,
213                plot_path=self.test_acc_plot_path,
214            )
215
216    def save_test_acc_to_csv(
217        self,
218        csv_path: str,
219    ) -> None:
220        r"""Save the test accuracy metrics of all tasks in multi-task learning to an CSV file.
221
222        **Args:**
223        - **csv_path** (`str`): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/acc.csv'.
224        """
225        all_task_ids = list(self.acc_test.keys())
226        fieldnames = ["average_accuracy"] + [
227            f"test_on_task_{task_id}" for task_id in all_task_ids
228        ]
229        new_line = {}
230
231        # construct the columns and calculate the average accuracy over tasks at the same time
232        average_accuracy_over_tasks = MeanMetric().to(
233            device=next(iter(self.acc_test.values())).device
234        )
235        for task_id in all_task_ids:
236            acc = self.acc_test[task_id].compute().item()
237            new_line[f"test_on_task_{task_id}"] = acc
238            average_accuracy_over_tasks(acc)
239        new_line["average_accuracy"] = average_accuracy_over_tasks.compute().item()
240
241        # write
242        with open(csv_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as file:
243            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
244            writer.writeheader()
245            writer.writerow(new_line)
246
247    def plot_test_acc_from_csv(self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str) -> None:
248        """Plot the test accuracy bar chart of all tasks in multi-task learning from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.
249
250        **Args:**
251        - **csv_path** (`str`): the path to the csv file where the `utils.save_test_acc_csv()` saved the test accuracy metric.
252        - **plot_path** (`str`): the path to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/acc.png'.
253        """
254        data = pd.read_csv(csv_path)
255
256        # extract all accuracy columns including average
257        all_columns = data.columns.tolist()
258        task_ids = list(range(len(all_columns)))  # assign index-based positions
259        labels = [
260            (
261                col.replace("test_on_task_", "Task ")
262                if "test_on_task_" in col
263                else "Average"
264            )
265            for col in all_columns
266        ]
267        accuracies = data.iloc[0][all_columns].values
268
269        # plot the accuracy bar chart over tasks
270        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(16, 9))
271        ax.bar(
272            task_ids,
273            accuracies,
274            color="skyblue",
275            edgecolor="black",
276        )
277        ax.set_xlabel("Task", fontsize=16)
278        ax.set_ylabel("Accuracy", fontsize=16)
279        ax.grid(True)
280        ax.set_xticks(task_ids)
281        ax.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha="right", fontsize=14)
282        ax.set_yticks([i * 0.05 for i in range(21)])
283        ax.set_yticklabels(
284            [f"{tick:.2f}" for tick in [i * 0.05 for i in range(21)]], fontsize=14
285        )
286        fig.tight_layout()
287        fig.savefig(plot_path)
288        plt.close(fig)

Provides all actions that are related to MTL accuracy metrics, which include:

  • Defining, initializing and recording accuracy metric.
  • Logging training and validation accuracy metric to Lightning loggers in real time.
  • Saving test accuracy metric to files.
  • Visualizing test accuracy metric as plots.

The callback is able to produce the following outputs:

  • CSV files for test accuracy of all tasks and average accuracy.
  • Bar charts for test accuracy of all tasks.

def plot_test_acc_from_csv(self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str) -> None: 
247    def plot_test_acc_from_csv(self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str) -> None:
248        """Plot the test accuracy bar chart of all tasks in multi-task learning from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.
249
250        **Args:**
251        - **csv_path** (`str`): the path to the csv file where the `utils.save_test_acc_csv()` saved the test accuracy metric.
252        - **plot_path** (`str`): the path to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/acc.png'.
253        """

258        task_ids = list(range(len(all_columns)))  # assign index-based positions
259        labels = [
260            (
261                col.replace("test_on_task_", "Task ")

263                else "Average"
264            )
265            for col in all_columns
266        ]

269        # plot the accuracy bar chart over tasks
270        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(16, 9))
271        ax.bar(
272            task_ids,
273            accuracies,
274            color="skyblue",
275            edgecolor="black",
276        )
277        ax.set_xlabel("Task", fontsize=16)
278        ax.set_ylabel("Accuracy", fontsize=16)
279        ax.grid(True)
280        ax.set_xticks(task_ids)
281        ax.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha="right", fontsize=14)
282        ax.set_yticks([i * 0.05 for i in range(21)])
283        ax.set_yticklabels(
284            [f"{tick:.2f}" for tick in [i * 0.05 for i in range(21)]], fontsize=14
285        )
286        fig.tight_layout()
287        fig.savefig(plot_path)
288        plt.close(fig)

Plot the test accuracy bar chart of all tasks in multi-task learning from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.

Args:

  • csv_path (str): the path to the csv file where the utils.save_test_acc_csv() saved the test accuracy metric.
  • plot_path (str): the path to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/acc.png'.
class MTLLoss(clarena.metrics.MetricCallback): 
 26class MTLLoss(MetricCallback):
 27    r"""Provides all actions that are related to MTL loss metrics, which include:
 28
 29    - Defining, initializing and recording loss metrics.
 30    - Logging training and validation loss metrics to Lightning loggers in real time.
 31    - Saving test loss metrics to files.
 32    - Visualizing test loss metrics as plots.
 33
 34    The callback is able to produce the following outputs:
 35
 36    - CSV files for test classification loss of all tasks and average classification loss.
 37    - Bar charts for test classification loss of all tasks.
 38    """
 39
 40    def __init__(
 41        self,
 42        save_dir: str,
 43        test_loss_cls_csv_name: str = "loss_cls.csv",
 44        test_loss_cls_plot_name: str | None = None,
 45    ) -> None:
 46        r"""Initialize the `MTLLoss`.
 47
 48        **Args:**
 49        - **save_dir** (`str`): The directory where data and figures of metrics will be saved. Better inside the output folder.
 50        - **test_loss_cls_csv_name**(`str`): file name to save classification loss of all tasks and average classification loss as CSV file.
 51        - **test_loss_cls_plot_name** (`str` | `None`): file name to save classification loss plot. If `None`, no file will be saved.
 52        """
 53        super().__init__(save_dir=save_dir)
 54
 55        # paths
 56        self.test_loss_cls_csv_path: str = os.path.join(
 57            save_dir, test_loss_cls_csv_name
 58        )
 59        r"""The path to save test classification loss of all tasks and average classification loss CSV file."""
 60        if test_loss_cls_plot_name:
 61            self.test_loss_cls_plot_path: str = os.path.join(
 62                save_dir, test_loss_cls_plot_name
 63            )
 64            r"""The path to save test classification loss plot."""
 65
 66        # training accumulated metrics
 67        self.loss_cls_training_epoch: MeanMetricBatch
 68        r"""Classification loss of training epoch. Accumulated and calculated from the training batches. """
 69
 70        # validation accumulated metrics
 71        self.loss_cls_val: dict[int, MeanMetricBatch] = {}
 72        r"""Validation classification loss of the model after training epoch. Accumulated and calculated from the validation batches. Keys are task IDs and values are the corresponding metrics. """
 73
 74        # test accumulated metrics
 75        self.loss_cls_test: dict[int, MeanMetricBatch] = {}
 76        r"""Test classification loss of all tasks. Accumulated and calculated from the test batches. Keys are task IDs and values are the corresponding metrics. """
 77
 78    def on_fit_start(self, trainer: Trainer, pl_module: MTLAlgorithm) -> None:
 79        r"""Initialize training and validation metrics."""
 80
 81        # initialize training metrics
 82        self.loss_cls_training_epoch = MeanMetricBatch()
 83
 84        # initialize validation metrics
 85        self.loss_cls_val = {
 86            task_id: MeanMetricBatch() for task_id in trainer.datamodule.train_tasks
 87        }
 88
 89    def on_train_batch_end(
 90        self,
 91        trainer: Trainer,
 92        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
 93        outputs: dict[str, Any],
 94        batch: Any,
 95        batch_idx: int,
 96    ) -> None:
 97        r"""Record training metrics from training batch, log metrics of training batch and accumulated metrics of the epoch to Lightning loggers.
 98
 99        **Args:**
100        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the training step, the returns of the `training_step()` method in the `MTLAlgorithm`.
101        - **batch** (`Any`): the training data batch.
102        """
103        # get the batch size
104        batch_size = len(batch)
105
106        # get training metrics values of current training batch from the outputs of the `training_step()`
107        loss_cls_batch = outputs["loss_cls"]
108
109        # update accumulated training metrics to calculate training metrics of the epoch
110        self.loss_cls_training_epoch.update(loss_cls_batch, batch_size)
111
112        # log training metrics of current training batch to Lightning loggers
113        pl_module.log("train/loss_cls_batch", loss_cls_batch, prog_bar=True)
114
115        # log accumulated training metrics till this training batch to Lightning loggers
116        pl_module.log(
117            "task/train/loss_cls",
118            self.loss_cls_training_epoch.compute(),
119            prog_bar=True,
120        )
121
122    def on_train_epoch_end(
123        self,
124        trainer: Trainer,
125        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
126    ) -> None:
127        r"""Log metrics of training epoch to plot learning curves and reset the metrics accumulation at the end of training epoch."""
128
129        # log the accumulated and computed metrics of the epoch to Lightning loggers, specially for plotting learning curves
130        pl_module.log(
131            "learning_curve/train/loss_cls",
132            self.loss_cls_training_epoch.compute(),
133            on_epoch=True,
134            prog_bar=True,
135        )
136
137        # reset the metrics of training epoch as there are more epochs to go and not only one epoch like in the validation and test
138        self.loss_cls_training_epoch.reset()
139
140    def on_validation_batch_end(
141        self,
142        trainer: Trainer,
143        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
144        outputs: dict[str, Any],
145        batch: Any,
146        batch_idx: int,
147        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
148    ) -> None:
149        r"""Accumulating metrics from validation batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of validation batches.
150
151        **Args:**
152        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the validation step, which is the returns of the `validation_step()` method in the `MTLAlgorithm`.
153        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
154        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of the validation dataloader. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
155        """
156        # get the batch size
157        batch_size = len(batch)
158
159        # map dataloader index to task id
160        val_task_id = pl_module.get_val_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
161
162        # get the metrics values of the batch from the outputs
163        loss_cls_batch = outputs["loss_cls"]
164
165        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the validation metrics
166        self.loss_cls_val[val_task_id].update(loss_cls_batch, batch_size)
167
168    def on_validation_epoch_end(
169        self,
170        trainer: Trainer,
171        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
172    ) -> None:
173        r"""Log validation metrics to plot learning curves."""
174
175        # compute average validation loss over tasks for logging learning curves
176        average_val_loss = MeanMetric().to(
177            device=next(iter(self.loss_cls_val.values())).device
178        )
179        for metric in self.loss_cls_val.values():
180            average_val_loss(metric.compute())
181
182        pl_module.log(
183            "learning_curve/val/loss_cls",
184            average_val_loss.compute(),
185            on_epoch=True,
186            prog_bar=True,
187        )
188
189    def on_test_start(
190        self,
191        trainer: Trainer,
192        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
193    ) -> None:
194        r"""Initialize the metrics for testing each seen task in the beginning of a task's testing."""
195
196        # initialize test metrics for current and previous tasks
197        self.loss_cls_test = {
198            task_id: MeanMetricBatch() for task_id in trainer.datamodule.eval_tasks
199        }
200
201    def on_test_batch_end(
202        self,
203        trainer: Trainer,
204        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
205        outputs: dict[str, Any],
206        batch: Any,
207        batch_idx: int,
208        dataloader_idx: int = 0,
209    ) -> None:
210        r"""Accumulating metrics from test batch. We don't need to log and monitor the metrics of test batches.
211
212        **Args:**
213        - **outputs** (`dict[str, Any]`): the outputs of the test step, which is the returns of the `test_step()` method in the `MTLAlgorithm`.
214        - **batch** (`Any`): the validation data batch.
215        - **dataloader_idx** (`int`): the task ID of seen tasks to be tested. A default value of 0 is given otherwise the LightningModule will raise a `RuntimeError`.
216        """
217
218        # get the batch size
219        batch_size = len(batch)
220
221        test_task_id = pl_module.get_test_task_id_from_dataloader_idx(dataloader_idx)
222
223        # get the metrics values of the batch from the outputs
224        loss_cls_batch = outputs["loss_cls"]
225
226        # update the accumulated metrics in order to calculate the metrics of the epoch
227        self.loss_cls_test[test_task_id].update(loss_cls_batch, batch_size)
228
229    def on_test_epoch_end(
230        self,
231        trainer: Trainer,
232        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,
233    ) -> None:
234        r"""Save and plot test metrics at the end of test."""
235
236        # save (update) the test metrics to CSV files
237        self.save_test_loss_cls_to_csv(
238            csv_path=self.test_loss_cls_csv_path,
239        )
240
241        # plot the test metrics
242        if self.test_loss_cls_plot_path:
243            self.plot_test_loss_cls_from_csv(
244                csv_path=self.test_loss_cls_csv_path,
245                plot_path=self.test_loss_cls_plot_path,
246            )
247
248    def save_test_loss_cls_to_csv(
249        self,
250        csv_path: str,
251    ) -> None:
252        r"""Save the test classification loss metrics of all tasks in multi-task learning to an CSV file.
253
254        **Args:**
255        - **csv_path** (`str`): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/loss_cls.csv'.
256        """
257        all_task_ids = list(self.loss_cls_test.keys())
258        fieldnames = ["average_classification_loss"] + [
259            f"test_on_task_{task_id}" for task_id in all_task_ids
260        ]
261        new_line = {}
262
263        # construct the columns and calculate the average loss over tasks at the same time
264        average_loss_over_tasks = MeanMetric().to(
265            device=next(iter(self.loss_cls_test.values())).device
266        )
267        for task_id in all_task_ids:
268            loss = self.loss_cls_test[task_id].compute().item()
269            new_line[f"test_on_task_{task_id}"] = loss
270            average_loss_over_tasks(loss)
271        new_line["average_classification_loss"] = (
272            average_loss_over_tasks.compute().item()
273        )
274
275        # write
276        with open(csv_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as file:
277            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
278            writer.writeheader()
279            writer.writerow(new_line)
280
281    def plot_test_loss_cls_from_csv(self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str) -> None:
282        """Plot the test classification loss bar chart of all tasks in multi-task learning from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.
283
284        **Args:**
285        - **csv_path** (`str`): the path to the csv file where the `utils.save_test_acc_csv()` saved the test classification loss metric.
286        - **plot_path** (`str`): the path to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/loss_cls.png'.
287        """
288        data = pd.read_csv(csv_path)
289
290        # extract all accuracy columns including average
291        all_columns = data.columns.tolist()
292        task_ids = list(range(len(all_columns)))  # assign index-based positions
293        labels = [
294            (
295                col.replace("test_on_task_", "Task ")
296                if "test_on_task_" in col
297                else "Average"
298            )
299            for col in all_columns
300        ]
301        loss_cls = data.iloc[0][all_columns].values
302
303        # plot the classification loss bar chart over tasks
304        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(16, 9))
305        ax.bar(
306            task_ids,
307            loss_cls,
308            color="skyblue",
309            edgecolor="black",
310        )
311        ax.set_xlabel("Task", fontsize=16)
312        ax.set_ylabel("Classification Loss", fontsize=16)
313        ax.grid(True)
314        ax.set_xticks(task_ids)
315        ax.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha="right", fontsize=14)
316        ax.set_yticks([i * 0.05 for i in range(21)])
317        ax.set_yticklabels(
318            [f"{tick:.2f}" for tick in [i * 0.05 for i in range(21)]], fontsize=14
319        )
320        fig.tight_layout()
321        fig.savefig(plot_path)
322        plt.close(fig)

def on_test_epoch_end( self, trainer: lightning.pytorch.trainer.trainer.Trainer, pl_module: clarena.mtl_algorithms.base.MTLAlgorithm) -> None: 
229    def on_test_epoch_end(
230        self,
231        trainer: Trainer,
232        pl_module: MTLAlgorithm,

245                plot_path=self.test_loss_cls_plot_path,
246            )

Save and plot test metrics at the end of test.

def save_test_loss_cls_to_csv(self, csv_path: str) -> None: 
248    def save_test_loss_cls_to_csv(
249        self,
250        csv_path: str,
251    ) -> None:
252        r"""Save the test classification loss metrics of all tasks in multi-task learning to an CSV file.
253
254        **Args:**
255        - **csv_path** (`str`): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/loss_cls.csv'.
256        """
257        all_task_ids = list(self.loss_cls_test.keys())
258        fieldnames = ["average_classification_loss"] + [
259            f"test_on_task_{task_id}" for task_id in all_task_ids
260        ]
261        new_line = {}
262
263        # construct the columns and calculate the average loss over tasks at the same time
264        average_loss_over_tasks = MeanMetric().to(
265            device=next(iter(self.loss_cls_test.values())).device
266        )
267        for task_id in all_task_ids:
268            loss = self.loss_cls_test[task_id].compute().item()
269            new_line[f"test_on_task_{task_id}"] = loss
270            average_loss_over_tasks(loss)
271        new_line["average_classification_loss"] = (
272            average_loss_over_tasks.compute().item()
273        )
274
275        # write
276        with open(csv_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as file:
277            writer = csv.DictWriter(file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
278            writer.writeheader()
279            writer.writerow(new_line)

Save the test classification loss metrics of all tasks in multi-task learning to an CSV file.

Args:

  • csv_path (str): save the test metric to path. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/results/loss_cls.csv'.
def plot_test_loss_cls_from_csv(self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str) -> None: 
281    def plot_test_loss_cls_from_csv(self, csv_path: str, plot_path: str) -> None:
282        """Plot the test classification loss bar chart of all tasks in multi-task learning from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.
283
284        **Args:**
285        - **csv_path** (`str`): the path to the csv file where the `utils.save_test_acc_csv()` saved the test classification loss metric.
286        - **plot_path** (`str`): the path to save plot. Better same as the output directory of the experiment. E.g. './outputs/expr_name/1970-01-01_00-00-00/loss_cls.png'.
287        """
288        data = pd.read_csv(csv_path)
289
290        # extract all accuracy columns including average
291        all_columns = data.columns.tolist()
292        task_ids = list(range(len(all_columns)))  # assign index-based positions
293        labels = [
294            (
295                col.replace("test_on_task_", "Task ")
296                if "test_on_task_" in col
297                else "Average"
298            )
299            for col in all_columns
300        ]
301        loss_cls = data.iloc[0][all_columns].values
302
303        # plot the classification loss bar chart over tasks
304        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(16, 9))
305        ax.bar(
306            task_ids,
307            loss_cls,
308            color="skyblue",
309            edgecolor="black",
310        )
311        ax.set_xlabel("Task", fontsize=16)
312        ax.set_ylabel("Classification Loss", fontsize=16)
313        ax.grid(True)
314        ax.set_xticks(task_ids)
315        ax.set_xticklabels(labels, rotation=45, ha="right", fontsize=14)
316        ax.set_yticks([i * 0.05 for i in range(21)])
317        ax.set_yticklabels(
318            [f"{tick:.2f}" for tick in [i * 0.05 for i in range(21)]], fontsize=14
319        )
320        fig.tight_layout()
321        fig.savefig(plot_path)
322        plt.close(fig)

Plot the test classification loss bar chart of all tasks in multi-task learning from saved CSV file and save the plot to the designated directory.

Args:
